by Bill Riesen
Four committees were
established recently to examine
the area major programs and to
recommend changes to the
Committee on Undergraduate
Studies and the Academic
Council.
"The purpose of the committees is to look at the area majors, see what we're doing, and
to try to come up with recommendations to improve them,"
said Associate Dean of Academic Studies Lucien Brush.
Brush explained that a review
of the area majors was first suggested last spring at a meeting
of Arts and Sciences depart-

ment chairmen. "There were
questions by the chairs like,
'Are area majors really taken
care of adequately? Is the curriculum they follow a good
one?' There was varied opinion
about the area major programs," he said.
A committee was established
in the fall to evaluate programs
in the humanities and part of
the committee's charge is to
assess the Humanities Area Major. The committee is chaired
by Professor of English Ronald
Paulson.

TEP,Fem. Alliance to Sponsor Lectures Campus
The TEP newsletter lives on!
In yet another action resulting
from that incident, a new, fourpart lecture series on sexual
harassment has been established.
The series, which will begin
next Tuesday, will be cosponsored by TEP, the Feminist Alliance, the Office of Student Activities, and the Office
of Residential Life.
When an obscene "TEP

newsletter" was released last
semester by the Feminist
Alliance, causing campus-wide
furor, the fraternity agreed to
work with the women's group
to establish programs to better
educate the Hopkins community on sexual harassment. This
new lecture series is the result.
The speakers and topics were
chosen by a committee which
included members of the
Feminist Alliance, represen-

Less Illness in Dorms
Continued from Page 1
according to Donald Torres:
director of the Bureau of Community Hygiene.
The results of the drinking
water tests are not yet available,
but according to Torres, and
examination of the swimming
pool's logs showed that on Sunday, the free chlorine residual
ratio was 0.3 parts per million
around 3:00 o'clock and 0.4
ppm at 7:00. Torres said,"We
recommend a level of 0.5 ppm
but 0.3-0.4 ppm should usually be adequate."
He added,"On Monday, the
ratio was up to 1.0-1.2 ppm
which is quite good."
According to Dwyer, symptoms that characterize the
sickness are similar to those of
gastroenteritis:
nausea,
vomiting, muscle cramps, abdominal pain, and perhaps a
fever. She added that about 50
people reported being sick.
According to Torres, the City Health Department is a code
enforcement agency, and as

such, can take punitive action
against establishments that
violate health standards. But
Torres said, "There was no
violation of food handling procedure at the Terrace Room so
I don't anticipate that we will
be taking punitive action
against the cafeteria. We will,
however, be returning a couple
of times in the near future to inspect the cafeteria's plumbing
and some other aspects of the
operation."
For the time being, the investigators are awaiting the
results of the water tests and
some other tests which should
be out "any time now."
Torres said that "If food is
implicated—and it's still an
if—it would appear that it was
a one shot outbreak, the kind
of freak accident that is not
humanly possible to prevent."
Dwyer concluded that
"We're all working on this
together. We may never really
know what it was, but the important thing is that it appears
to have subsided." .

Porter and Director of Residential Life Andrea Perry.
The first lecture will be Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. in the L/V
Room. It will be titled "Sexual
Politics in the Professional
Workplace," and will address,
according to the program,
"issues of sexual harassment in
legal, medical, and academic
institutions." The forum will
also provide "legal definitions"
of sexual harassment.
This seminar will feature
three speakers: Valerie Kaiser,
Carolyn Polowi, and Margaret
Dunkle. Kaiser is a resident in
Psychiatry at North Shore
Community Hospital in New
York. Polowi is a Baltimore attorney who has handled
numerous sexual harassment
cases. Dunkle is the co-director
of the Equality Center in
Washington, D.C. She was the
first chairman of the National
Coalition for Women and Girls
in Education, and co-authored
Exploitation From 9 to 5,
which is about sexual harassment in the workplace. She was
also associate director of the
Project on the Status and
Education of Women, Association of American Colleges.
The second forum in the
series will be on Thursday, Feb.
28 in the AMR I Multi-Purpose
Room, and will be called
"Social Cues and Miscues: Sexual Roles in a Social Setting."
The speaker will be Susan
Walen, director of the
Baltimore Center for Cognitive
Therapy and an associate professor of Psychology at Towson

State University. Her talk will
focus on "male-female interaction...especially on college
campuses."
"Sex in Advertising" will be
the topic of the third speech in
the series, to be given by Mark
Miller. Miller is an assistant
professor in the Writing
Seminars Departmen. To be
held in the AMR I MultiPurpose Room, this seminar
will "examine sexual messages
contained in popular advertisements."
The final event in the series
will be centered around a film,
Pornography—Not a Love
Story, which will be shown in
the L/V Room on Monday,
March 11. Afterward, a discussion of the film will be led by
Greg Reising, coordinator of
Clinical Services at the Towson
State University Counseling
Center. The film examines
"sexual attitudes conveyed by
pornographic images."
All of the lectures will be held
at 7:30 p.m.
Tami Oki, co-director of the
Feminist Alliance, said her
group is satisfied with the
series. When asked how the
groups on the committee, some
of which have obviously clashed in the past, worked together,
Oki said, "It went OK."
Paul Connaughton, chancellor of TEP,said the committee
worked well together, and that
the fraternity was also satisfied
with the speakers selected.
Both Connaughton and Oki
said that it was at times difficult
to find speakers who were sufficiently knowledgable about
sexual harassment.

Science" will be the topic of a
lecture series at
new
Homewood this spring.

Judson said he wanted to

"I then turned to what is
really the other half of the program," Judson said, "which is

Continued from Page 1
protests at the South African
embassy and briefing the
students before going to the
protest site.
"The Trans-Africa organization helped alleviate the
students' apprehension with the
right element of humor to ease
the tension. They reminded us
of the past success of the protest," said Keim.
The students were loaded onto buses and driven to the protest site. This site was a couple
blocks away from the South
African embassy because it is illegal to protest within five hundred feet of an embassy.
Keim said that the remarkable aspect of the protest was
the incredible spirit of those involved. "It was freezing, cold,
and windy, but the students remained undaunted in their pro-

test."
The students marched with
signs across the street from
other demonstrators on
Massachusetts Avenue. Keim
estimated that there were at least
200-300 people picketing. "The
spirit was tremendous," continued Keim. "People driving
by were honking at the
picketers and we were given an
ovation as we walked by."
"We listened to speakers and
they really helped to inspire the
group," said Keim. The
students then took a bus to the
arrest site which was in front of
the South African embassy.
While on the bus, the students
were interviewed by the
Baltimore News-American. The
protesters were greeted by an
unusually large number of D.C.
policemen. The protesters, singing "We Shall Overcome," remained in front of the embassy

for over one and a half hours
before they were arrested. "The
police were trying a standoff,"
said Keim. "However, I guess
the cold and the wind got to
them before us. The police were
surprised that the protesters
had such staying power."
Although it was a nervous
situation, the majority of the
protesters were arrested with
dignity. "The situation was
always under control. There
was no chance of violence,"
stated Keim.
The entire procedure was extremely organized. Those who
wished to be arrested wore
yellow armbands to eliminate
confusion among the protesters
and the police. The men and
women were taken away in
separate paddy wagons and to
separate cells. They were
restrained with plastic handcuffs, fingerprinted, tightly

"The entire procedure was really a formality," said Rosanne

March 14. However, Keim says

students were headed back for

Archeologist Speaks on Prehistoric Skeletons
by Frank Caprio
Paleontologist Alan Walker
lectured last Wednesday on his
recent East African expedition
with an archeological team led
by Dr. Richard Leakey. The
trip yielded a startling major
fossil discovery—a nearly complete skeleton of Homo erectus.
Walker, who is a professor
of cell biology and anatomy at
the School of Medicine, spoke
as part of the Wednesday Noon
Series. He began his talk with
a brief summary of previous
finds of Homo erectus, a
predecessor of Homo sapiens.
After Darwin published The
Descent of Man, German
zoologist Haeckel anticipated
the discovery of Homo erectus
as the "missing link" between
ape and man. Java Man and
Peking Man were the first major fossils of Homo erectus
uncovered.
The next major finding in
this area was the well-publicized
work of Dr. L. S. B. Leakey in
Tanzania's Olduvai Gorge in
the 1960s. A number of
valuable fossils was found by
another member of the Leakey
family, Richard Leakey, in the
1970s at the Koobi Fora site on
the eastern shore of Lake
Turkana in Kenya. Included
among these was a Homo erectus who had suffered from
periostitis, an inflammatory
bone disease due to an excess of
dietary vitamin A which is present in high levels in the livers
of carnivores. This is strong

evidence that man was still
primarily a hunter when Homo
erectus appeared 1.5 to 2
million years ago. However,
while these fossils led many to
postulate the importance of
Homo erectus in the course of
human evolution, the evidence
was still fragmentary and
inconclusive.
During August and September of last year, Walker
worked with Leakey at a site on
the western shore of Lake
Turkana near the Sudanese
border. A section of jawbone
was found and led to an exploration of the site which
yielded a nearly complete skull
which was pieced together from
over 70 fragments. Further excavation resulted in the
discovery of a nearly complete
Homo erectus skeleton scattered throughout sedimentary
particles in the remnants of a
prehistoric swamp. Based on
the dental eruption and growth
plates on bones, the specimen
was determined to be about 12
years of age in modern human
terms. The prehistoric pre-teen
was identified as a male by the
structure of the pelvic bone and
geochemical dating techniques
show that the fossils are 1.6
million years old. The bone
structure clearly shows that the
boy was well over six feet and
a review of fragments of other
Homo erectus fossils showed
that man has been getting
smaller in stature as evolution
continues.

Letters
More on Fraternities
To the Editor:
Mr. Warren's article of last
week concerning the history of
fraternities at Johns Hopkins illuminates many of the problems that exist within the
fraternities and their relationship with the university. By
comparing the student involvement (and behavior) of today,
one might predict a general
decline for these social
organizations with a forseeable
conclusion. But that rationalization would be based on
a few well-publicized events and
not include the overall change
in the fraternities that has occurred over the past few years.
To be more precise, this past
year every fraternity has taken
extraordinary measures (in
comparison to past measures)
to cooperate with the university and neighbors. This fall the
Inter-Fraternity Council, after
consulting with the university,
passed a resolution on "Open
Party Policy," dramatically
curbing problems that accompanied these events. New
restrictions were enforced on
activity outside the houses: the
number of kegs allowed, the
time parties were to break up,
etc. Fraternities also tried to improve their image by sponsoring athletic and relay games
during a "Greek Weekend."

While this event received little
publicity, it was an effort by the
I.F.C. to show that frats were
not just "the party." Most
recently, the I.F.C. "dried out
Rush," for all intents and purposes, by recommending fines
for fraternities that the university and I.F.C. felt had violated
Rush policies. (This was an inevitable event that has ocurred
at most colleges where the state
drinking age has risen.) This
latest action demonstrates the
fraternities' collective will to
police themselves and to conform to the prevailing attitudes
of the university and the nation
in regards to alcohol. A letter
that appeared in the NewsLetter two weeks ago commented on the alterations in the
fraternity parties in just the past
few years. It should be clear to
the university and students that
frats have drastically cleaned up
their act in the past few years.
Even with all the changes
that fraternities have implemented, does this mean the
brothers have acquired halos
and do only good deeds? Certainly not. Fraternities must
understand what has brought
down the weight of the administration, neighbors, and
every anti-alcohol interest on
their shoulders. The drinking
law changed and frats didn't.
We kept on throwing open
parties—calmer than their wild
predecessors of the 1970's—yet,

"open" nonetheless. The
university could not help but
raise an eyebrow when young
students staggered into the
dorms with tales of drunkeness
and debauchery in smoke-filled
rooms. Each tale was exaggerated and amplified until the
administration was presented a
picture of Hopkins fraternities
as being the source of evil in the
modern world.
What,then, is the answer for
frats? The answer is mellow-out
the parties. We need only to
look into our own histories to
find the answer to our recent
problems. Prior to 1973, the
drinking age in Maryland was
21. According to alumni, parties occurred—but were usually closed, well-tempered,
discrete affairs. Because of the
fraternities' self-imposed
restraint, the university saw no
need to intervene. (Given this,
the university's current charge
of underage serving at fraternities is somewhat unfair.)
Hopkins fraternities should
take a lesson from the alumni
and exercise much more discretion at parties, probably making them invitation events.
Fraternities must change with
the growing tide and recognize
their responsibilities to the community and the university. If
they don't, they'll perish.
The university must similarly change its attitude towards
the role of fraternities at Johns

Bradford Fitch

Things To Do After Graduation From Hopkins
by Mike Kun
I remember when I was at
Hopkins how people just disappeared after they graduated,
and you never knew if they
made a lot of money or ended
up in a detention home or what.
Anyhow, I thought you might
like to know what happens to
a typical Hopkins alumnus in
his first year out of school.
So, here's my life since
graduation. I hope you enjoy it
more than I have.
1. Dinner
Right after graduation
everybody goes out to dinner
with their families. But since
my sister and brother-in-law
showed up at the last minute
with their kid, there wasn't
enough room for everyone in
the car. So I stayed, and they
all went out to eat. No kidding,
I really did. I ended up eating
half a pizza over at P.J.'s.
which wasn't so bad at all considering I found out later about
the scene my dad made at the
restaurant where they went. He
didn't have reservations, so he
told the hostess he had tuberculosis. Then he pretty much
had his pick of tables.
2. Lacrosse finals
I locked my keys in my car,
and a couple guys from
Syracuse offered to give me a
hand getting them out, which I
figured was pretty nice since
their team had just lost the
championship. It would've
been even nicer if they'd explained to me beforehand that
they were going to use large
rocks to do it. Anyway, they
got the keys out, and I probably
ended up saving a ton of money
because I didn't have to use the
air-conditioner all summer.
3. Work
This gigantic company gave
me a job for the summer. I
would tell you what I did, but
even now I'm not quite sure.
They sure did give me a lot of
money for doing it, though.

4. Movies
I saw a bunch of movies
because I had so much money
from working for this gigantic
company. Anyway, I saw this
one really terrific one. I don't
remember the name of it. Or
who was in it. Or what it was
about. But you should see it if
you have a chance. You really
should.
5. Weddings
Practically everybody I know
got married right after graduation, so I ended up having to,
buy a million wine decanters. I
have no idea at all what you're
supposed to do with them. I
mean, I know you're supposed
to use them for wine, but
everyone I know drinks wine
right out of the bottle. Maybe
you're supposed to pour it in
this first. Who knows?
Anyway, my mom said I should
buy them, and she knows about
these things since most of her
friends have been married halfa-dozen times each.
• 6. Weird
I think I started missing all of
my friends from Hopkins too
much because all of a sudden
my mind just went berserk on
me, and I started thinking these
really weird things. Like, what
if chocolate were poisonous. I'd
bet people wouldn't eat so
much of it then. Have you ever
thought of that? Well, it's true.
7. More weddings
This girl I used to date got
married, which put me in a rotten mood. So I found out what
hotel they were staying in on
their wedding night and kept
calling up to say that there was
a bomb in one of the rooms. I
know that's probably illegal or
something, but I really got a
kick out of it.
8. Clothes
I still had a lot of money
from working for that gigantic
company, so I bought all of
these super clothes. The only
problem was that they looked
better on those mannequins
than on me. Like this Indiana

Jones hat I bought, for instance, makes me look more
like Don Knotts than Indiana
Jones. I would've taken it back
except that girls really like the
way Don Knotts looks. Really.
My sister told me that.
9. Law school
I went to law school. For
three weeks. I'd really rather
not talk about this except to
make it clear that I did not get
thrown out like everyone thinks
I did. I mean, the only way you
could possibly get thrown out
of law school after three weeks
would be if you failed orientation, which 1 didn't. I swear.
You could ask the dean.
10. Writing
I decided to combine my
political science background
with my love of fiction and
came up with some great
stories. Tell me what you think
of these: "Rasputin Goes to
Baskin-Robbins," "William
the Conqueror Coaches a Little League Baseball Team,"
"George S. Patton Bakes a
Seven-Layer Cake," and
"Lord Mountbatten Eats a
Live German Shepherd."
Don't expect to see any of these
in print though—it looks like
The New Yorker has this thing
about not printing young
writers. What a bunch of jerks.
11. Joke
A friend told me a good
joke. It's hilarious, and I'm
practically falling out of my
chair just thinking about it. Remind me to tell you sometime.
12. Money
I spent all of the money I'd
made from that gigantic company, so I had to start borrowing from friends and selling
things just to get by. I even sold
a station wagon for $500, which
was a pretty good deal since it
belonged to our next-door
neighbors, the Kaels, who were
at Great Adventure for the day.
I could've gotten $1000 for it if
I wanted to haggle, but I
figured why be a jerk.

Every once in a while I get
really bored and go visit a

will be forced to extend more

to send their children to an expensive private institution like

To send a child to a
prestigious private institution
costs money. This investment
can, however, be paid off by
the quality of the education and
the opportunities afforded by
attending such a school. By
making these schools economically unfeasible, Reagan will
return such schools to the
private preserve of the wealthy.
Middle and working class kids
will have to content themselves
with state schools. Private institutions will need to become
less competitive to ensure
enrollment from their dwindling applicants. The quality of
education in the United States
will decline as will its scope, for
fewer people will be able to afford college.
Those in special distress will
be families with several collegeaged students. How these
families will afford college during times of budget austerity is
uncertain. For example, if a
family in Pennsylvania makes
$32,501 and has four children
of college age, total tuition and
expenses would be over $28,000
if the children all went to Penn
State. I think Reagan needs to
be reminded that social programs are there for a reason. If
he believes that they are inefficient and corrupt, he should
reform them, not emasculate

them.
I have another question for
the President. He says that the
U.S. technological lead is imperative to national security.
How does he expect that lead to
be maintained if he cuts aid to
students that get higher quality
educations and exposure to
complex ideas and high
technology? Is the nation more
secure in having twenty more
MX missiles to add to our
stockpiles, or in advancing the
education of this nation's
children? Reagan seems to
prefer the missiles; after all,
they are in the budget.
If this budget passes, educational opportunities for the
middle and working classes will
become severely limited. One
can only hope that the Congress
has more sense than the Administration. The young of this
country deserve the very best
education possible. Not only is
the current level of aid possible,
but its cost should not be considered excessive, for without
it, America's future is in doubt.
Reagan is trying to turn back
the clock on education. In the
name of efficiency, he is making a quality higher education,
not a dream, but an impossibility. The American Dream that
generations have aspired to,
that of having their children get
the best education possible, will
die. The Reagan Revolution
will be remembered as the
beginning of the end for the
American higher educational
system.

To the Editor:
In response to last week's
editorial about the Awards process, I would like to clear up
some things and voice some
opinions. First of all, this is the

first time (I think) that every
senior was given a letter requesting nominations for Student Activities Awards(formerly known as SAC seals). This
was done to give everyone in
the class an opportunity to have
some say in who is chosen for
these awards.
This process was worked out
between the SAC Executive
Board and myself, representing
the Senior Class. Much of it
depends upon mutual understanding by the two parties, but
on the whole, it is structured
much better that it has been in
the past.
My real gripe is towards the
Senior Class, itself. The boxes
were stuffed on Feb. 1st, and
now, two weeks later, we have
next to nothing in the way of
nominations. Come on Seniors,
let's get with it! By opening the
awards process up to the
general public, it was meant to
include everyone who is interested, instead of a
mysterious decision-making
process in some dark, smokefilled room. If this response
reflects the true feelings of the
class, namely apathy, then there
is no reason to bother giving
out awards.
There are five more days to
nominate people for all awards.
We need input, now, people!!
If there is disastrously inadequate participation, then there
are two choices: either return
the process to dark, smokefilled rooms or get rid of
awards altogether. I leave that
choice to you.
Patiently waiting,
Doug Gordimer, Chairman

Quad Monitors
To the Editor:

On behalf of all the quad
monitors, I would like to take
this opportunity to thank Leanna Chamish for her letter in the
News-Letterlast week. We are
proud to say that she is not the
only one that feels safer because
of our presence in the quads.
For those who are unaware
of the quad monitor program,
let me briefly explain it. Between the hours of 6:00 p.m.
and 2:00 a.m., 7 days a week,
there will be monitors stationed in both the freshman and
Gilman quads. Their main purpose is to make sure all is quiet
in the quads. However, these
monitors are also open to give
foot escorts around campus or
just off Charles Street. During
the end of night school classes
(7:45-8:15 p.m.), one of the
monitors moves to the lower

Amniocentesis Yields Early Sickle Cell Detection
by Robin Gugenheim

The field of prenatal
diagnosis has grown in recent
years into an exciting and
diverse science. The recent advances are a result of applying
recombinant DNA techniques
to the various problems of
clinical medicine and genetics.
Haig Kazazian Jr., M.D.,
Director of the Genetics Unit in
the Department of Pediatrics at
Hopkins, began his research
with hemoglobinopathies,
various disorders of the red
blood cell protein hemoglobin,
around 1970. Kazazian, along
with Stylianos E. Antonarakis,
M.D., Alan Scott, Ph.D., and
Corinne D. Boehm, M.S., are
presently studying DNA from
families where sickle cell
anemia, beta-thalassemia, other
hemoglobinopathies, and
hemophilia traits are present.
When prenatal diagnosis
began in 1970 not much was
known about this intriguing
field. Researchers discovered
that the beta-globin chain of
hemoglobin, that would be affected in sickle-cell anemia and
beta-thalassemia, two genetic
disorders, is produced in early
fetal life. Therefore, it would be
biologically possible to carry

out prenatal detection of these
diseases if one could get a fetal
blood sample. This analysis
depended upon the actual protein product, beta-hemoglobin,
of the beta-globin gene.
Hobbins and Mahoney at
Yale, and other groups around
the world, started developing
fetoscopy around 1975, which
is used to obtain fetal blood
samples. This procedure,
although highly successful, carries a risk of about 3 to 4 percent fatality depending upon
the skill of the obstetrician.
This test entails putting a
fiberoptic scope, with a light
source, through the abdominal
wall, through the uterus, and
into the amniotic sac. The field
of vision is very small, such
that, when looking at the extremities, only a part of the
fetus's hand can be observed at
one time. Blood is then taken
from a placental vein on the inner surface near the fetus.
Y.W. Kan in San Francisco did
the first procedures for diagnosis of sickle cell anemia and
beta-thalasSemia in 1975-6.
Sickle cell anemia and betathalassemia are two genetic
disorders where the beta-globin
chain of hemoglobin carries a
mutation that alters its chemical
structure. Sickle cell anemia can

be deadly although about half
of its victims live to 35 or 40
years of age. The red blood
cells of afflicted individuals exhibit the characteristic sickle
shape that inspired the name of
the disease. Carriers, who only
possess one affected gene, exhibit a moderate sickling of
their red blood cells. Betathalassemia, a much more
severe disease, results from a
mutation in a single nucleotide
base or a deletion of a particular region of the beta-globin
gene. These patients must be
treated with frequent blood
transfusions, but the resulting
accumulation of iron causes
premature death for most
patients.
The use of recombinant
DNA technology in 1978 was a
major breakthrough for
prenatal
diagnosis
of
hemoglobinopathies. By using
the technique of Southern Blot
Analysis one could look at the
beta-globin gene itself. This
means that the hemoglobin
molecule isn't needed and
therefore, any cell from the
body may be used for analysis,
not just red blood cells. The
DNA could be obtained by the
known
as
procedure
amniocentesis.

Balloons Used to Treat Arteries
Wider use of the balloon inflation technique instead of
bypass surgery to treat narrowed or obstructed arteries in the
leg offers the potential for
substantial cost savings without
sacrificing good patient care,
according to investigators at the
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
"While overutilization of
diagnostic radiology has been a
popular theme to explain increasing medical costs,
underutilization of interventional radiology procedures,
such as the balloon technique,
also are a factor in rising
costs," they say.
In a group of 86 patients
treated at Hopkins Hospital,
the length of stay averaged 4 to
4.5 times longer, and the total
hospital charge was 3 to 3.7
times greater for the surgical
bypass group than for the
group treated with the balloon
technique—percutaneous
transluminal angioplasty
(PTA).
The findings were presented
at the recent Radiological
Society of North America
meeting in Washington, D.C.,
by a team led by Malonnie L.
Kinnison, M.D., assistant professor of radiology.
The investigators analyzed
costs in treating diseased portions of the femoral artery,
which extends from just below
the hip to the knee, and the iliac artery, which extends from
the navel to the crease at the top
of the leg.
When these arteries become
blocked by atherosclerotic plaque, surgeons traditionally have
corrected the problem by

removing a vein from some
other area of the body and grafting it to the artery above and
below the blockage—thereby
"bypassing" the trouble spot.
In PTA, interventional
radiologists thread a catheter
with a balloon tip into the
obstructed segment of the artery
and inflate the balloon with
fluid, thus forcing open the
blocked segment.
For femoral PTA, the
average patient bill was $2,767,
which was $5,431 less than for
bypass surgery. For iliac PTA,
the average bill was $3,075,
which was $7,148 less than a
comparable bypass. The differences are exclusive of professional fees which also are higher
for surgery than for the balloon
technique.
"PTA is less expensive,"
Kinnison explains, "because
the procedure does not require
surgery or general anesthesia,
as does the bypass, and because
the length of hospital stay is
shorter for PTA patients than
for bypass patients."
For instance, for femoral
PTA patients, the length of stay
is only 3.5 days, which is 12.3
days shorter than for bypass
patients. The average length of
stay for iliac PTA patients was
3.6 days, which is 11.1 days
shorter than for bypass
patients.
Furthermore, PTA often can
be performed at the time of the
x-ray diagnostic study of the
arteries that all of these patients
must undergo, even if they are
to be treated by surgery.
"PTA for peripheral
vascular disease is an example

of the new technological
are

underutilized from both a
clinical and financial viewpoint," the authors emphasize.
Among reasons they cited for
underutilization of PTA is the
patient referral pattern. Patients traditionally are seen first
by their internist or family
physician who refers them to a
surgeon. After diagnostic
angiography, the surgeon is
then responsible for treating the
patient.
"Either because of a lack of
information, lack of a
radiologist well-trained in
angioplasty techniques, or
simply a desire to perform a
familiar and reliable procedure,
patients are not referred for
PTA."
However, "These barriers
are rapidly being eliminated by
the information now available
on the efficacy of PTA, increasing numbers of wellinterventional
trained
radiologists, and better
educated consumers."
In addition, the investigators
note, changes in the way
hospitals are reimbursed should
offer them the financial incentive to choose the least costly
method of treatment. "While
not all patients are candidates
for PTA, and those with more
severe disease are referred for
surgery," the data in the new
paper "demonstrates the potential financial benefit of performing PTA rather than
operating on suitable patients,"
the authors point out.

DNA,still resulting in the same
protein. This polymorphism,
which is near the sickle mutation on the nucleotide chain,
was an excellent marker for the
mutation because the mutation
and the polymorphism are
usually inherited together. The
majority of sickle cell genes
contained the polymorphism
while nearly all normal genes
lacked it. Family studies could
then be done to determine

whether the presence of the
marker or lack of the marker
was coupled with the sickle cell
mutation.
Prenatal diagnosis was then
done by using cells from the
amniotic fluid obtained by amniocentesis. If the mother and
the father both have the sickle
cell marker, then one could
look for the presence of
markers in fetal cells to determine if the fetus is affected or
not. An affected fetus will have
two, sickle genes (SS), a carrier
has a normal gepe and a sickle

person has two normal genes

kinds of common diseases. Carriers may have either a high or

Enzyme Gene Code Uncovered
Robert P. Dottin;associate
professor of biology at
Hopkins, has cloned and sequenced the genetic code for
Creatine kinase (CK), an enzyme whose abnormal expression is associated with both
muscular dystrophy and cardiac hypertrophy. Cardiac
hypertrophy, which involves
enlargement of the heart, occurs in many people with
hypertension.
Dottin uncovered the
genetic code for the enzyme in
collaboration with two other
Hopkins researchers, and
reported the results in Nucleic
Acids Research, a journal

published in Great Britain.
"Although we still don't
understand the genetic factors
that control the synthesis of
this enzyme in persons with
muscular dystrophy or cardiac
hypertrophy, this is a major
advance in our research," said
Dottin. "This brings us one
step closer to understanding
what controls the expression
of the gene, which could
reveal the underlying causes
of these disorders."
Creatine kinase comes in
three different forms, and
each performs the same functions. In muscular dystrophy
and cardiac hypertrophy,

however, the relative amounts
of these forms change. Why
this happens, and why we
possess three forms of the
same enzyme, remains a
mystery.
Stress is probably a factor
in cardiac hypertrophy, since
the disease is associated with
hypertension. Finding the
connection, however, means
understanding a complex
series of biochemical events.
According to Dottin, "We
know very little about intermediate compounds that
are synthesized under stress
that may control expression of
the gene."

group," said Keim. The
students then took a bus to the
arrest site which was in front of
the South African embassy.
While on the bus, the students
were interviewed by the
Baltimore News-American. The
protesters were greeted by an
unusually large number of D.C.
policemen. The protesters, singing "We Shall Overcome," remained in front of the embassy

before they were arrested. "The
police were trying a standoff,"
said Keim. "However, I guess
the cold and the wind got to
them before us. The police were
surprised that the protesters
had such staying power."
Although it was a nervous
situation, the majority of the
protesters were arrested with
dignity. "The situation was
always under control. There
was no chance of violence,"
stated Keim.

wished to be arrested wore
yellow armbands to eliminate
confusion among the protesters
and the police. The men and
women were taken away in
separate paddy wagons and to
separate cells. They were
restrained with plastic handcuffs, fingerprinted, tightly

Archeologist Speaks on Prehistoric Skeletons
by Frank Caprio
Paleontologist Alan Walker
lectured last Wednesday on his
recent East African expedition
with an archeological team led
by Dr. Richard Leakey. The
trip yielded a startling major
fossil discovery—a nearly complete skeleton of Homo erectus.
Walker, who is a professor
of cell biology and anatomy at
the School of Medicine, spoke
as part of the Wednesday Noon
Series. He began his talk with
a brief summary of previous
finds of Homo erectus, a
predecessor of Homo sapiens.
After Darwin published The
Descent of Man, German
zoologist Haeckel anticipated
the discovery of Homo erectus
as the "missing link" between
ape and man. Java Man and
Peking Man were the first major fossils of Homo erectus
uncovered.
The next major finding in
this area was the well-publicized
work of Dr. L. S. B. Leakey in
Tanzania's Olduvai Gorge in
the 1960s. A number of
valuable fossils was found by
another member of the Leakey
family, Richard Leakey, in the
1970s at the Koobi Fora site on
the eastern shore of Lake
Turkana in Kenya. Included
among these was a Homo erectus who had suffered from
periostitis, an inflammatory
bone disease due to an excess of
dietary vitamin A which is present in high levels in the livers
of carnivores. This is strong

evidence that man was still
primarily a hunter when Homo
erectus appeared 1.5 to 2
million years ago. However,
while these fossils led many to
postulate the importance of
Homo erectus in the course of
human evolution, the evidence
was still fragmentary and
inconclusive.
During August and September of last year, Walker
worked with Leakey at a site on
the western shore of Lake
Turkana near the Sudanese
border. A section of jawbone
was found and led to an exploration of the site which
yielded a nearly complete skull
which was pieced together from
over 70 fragments. Further excavation resulted in the
discovery of a nearly complete
Homo erectus skeleton scattered throughout sedimentary
particles in the remnants of a
prehistoric swamp. Based on
the dental eruption and growth
plates on bones, the specimen
was determined to be about 12
years of age in modern human
terms. The prehistoric pre-teen
was identified as a male by the
structure of the pelvic bone and
geochemical dating techniques
show that the fossils are 1.6
million years old. The bone
structure clearly shows that the
boy was well over six feet and
a review of fragments of other
Homo erectus fossils showed
that man has been getting
smaller in stature as evolution
continues.

Letters
More on Fraternities
To the Editor:
Mr. Warren's article of last
week concerning the history of
fraternities at Johns Hopkins illuminates many of the problems that exist within the
fraternities and their relationship with the university. By
comparing the student involvement (and behavior) of today,
one might predict a general
decline for these social
organizations with a forseeable
conclusion. But that rationalization would be based on
a few well-publicized events and
not include the overall change
in the fraternities that has occurred over the past few years.
To be more precise, this past
year every fraternity has taken
extraordinary measures (in
comparison to past measures)
to cooperate with the university and neighbors. This fall the
Inter-Fraternity Council, after
consulting with the university,
passed a resolution on "Open
Party Policy," dramatically
curbing problems that accompanied these events. New
restrictions were enforced on
activity outside the houses: the
number of kegs allowed, the
time parties were to break up,
etc. Fraternities also tried to improve their image by sponsoring athletic and relay games
during a "Greek Weekend."

While this event received little
publicity, it was an effort by the
I.F.C. to show that frats were
not just "the party." Most
recently, the I.F.C. "dried out
Rush," for all intents and purposes, by recommending fines
for fraternities that the university and I.F.C. felt had violated
Rush policies. (This was an inevitable event that has ocurred
at most colleges where the state
drinking age has risen.) This
latest action demonstrates the
fraternities' collective will to
police themselves and to conform to the prevailing attitudes
of the university and the nation
in regards to alcohol. A letter
that appeared in the NewsLetter two weeks ago commented on the alterations in the
fraternity parties in just the past
few years. It should be clear to
the university and students that
frats have drastically cleaned up
their act in the past few years.
Even with all the changes
that fraternities have implemented, does this mean the
brothers have acquired halos
and do only good deeds? Certainly not. Fraternities must
understand what has brought
down the weight of the administration, neighbors, and
every anti-alcohol interest on
their shoulders. The drinking
law changed and frats didn't.
We kept on throwing open
parties—calmer than their wild
predecessors of the 1970's—yet,

"open" nonetheless. The
university could not help but
raise an eyebrow when young
students staggered into the
dorms with tales of drunkeness
and debauchery in smoke-filled
rooms. Each tale was exaggerated and amplified until the
administration was presented a
picture of Hopkins fraternities
as being the source of evil in the
modern world.
What,then, is the answer for
frats? The answer is mellow-out
the parties. We need only to
look into our own histories to
find the answer to our recent
problems. Prior to 1973, the
drinking age in Maryland was
21. According to alumni, parties occurred—but were usually closed, well-tempered,
discrete affairs. Because of the
fraternities' self-imposed
restraint, the university saw no
need to intervene. (Given this,
the university's current charge
of underage serving at fraternities is somewhat unfair.)
Hopkins fraternities should
take a lesson from the alumni
and exercise much more discretion at parties, probably making them invitation events.
Fraternities must change with
the growing tide and recognize
their responsibilities to the community and the university. If
they don't, they'll perish.
The university must similarly change its attitude towards
the role of fraternities at Johns

Bradford Fitch
President, Sigma Phi Epsilon

Things To Do After Graduation From Hopkins
by Mike Kun
I remember when I was at
Hopkins how people just disappeared after they graduated,
and you never knew if they
made a lot of money or ended
up in a detention home or what.
Anyhow, I thought you might
like to know what happens to
a typical Hopkins alumnus in
his first year out of school.
So, here's my life since
graduation. I hope you enjoy it
more than I have.
1. Dinner
Right after graduation
everybody goes out to dinner
with their families. But since
my sister and brother-in-law
showed up at the last minute
with their kid, there wasn't
enough room for everyone in
the car. So I stayed, and they
all went out to eat. No kidding,
I really did. I ended up eating
half a pizza over at P.J.'s.
which wasn't so bad at all considering I found out later about
the scene my dad made at the
restaurant where they went. He
didn't have reservations, so he
told the hostess he had tuberculosis. Then he pretty much
had his pick of tables.
2. Lacrosse finals
I locked my keys in my car,
and a couple guys from
Syracuse offered to give me a
hand getting them out, which I
figured was pretty nice since
their team had just lost the
championship. It would've
been even nicer if they'd explained to me beforehand that
they were going to use large
rocks to do it. Anyway, they
got the keys out, and I probably
ended up saving a ton of money
because I didn't have to use the
air-conditioner all summer.
3. Work
This gigantic company gave
me a job for the summer. I
would tell you what I did, but
even now I'm not quite sure.
They sure did give me a lot of
money for doing it, though.

4. Movies
I saw a bunch of movies
because I had so much money
from working for this gigantic
company. Anyway, I saw this
one really terrific one. I don't
remember the name of it. Or
who was in it. Or what it was
about. But you should see it if
you have a chance. You really
should.
5. Weddings
Practically everybody I know
got married right after graduation, so I ended up having to,
buy a million wine decanters. I
have no idea at all what you're
supposed to do with them. I
mean, I know you're supposed
to use them for wine, but
everyone I know drinks wine
right out of the bottle. Maybe
you're supposed to pour it in
this first. Who knows?
Anyway, my mom said I should
buy them, and she knows about
these things since most of her
friends have been married halfa-dozen times each.
• 6. Weird
I think I started missing all of
my friends from Hopkins too
much because all of a sudden
my mind just went berserk on
me, and I started thinking these
really weird things. Like, what
if chocolate were poisonous. I'd
bet people wouldn't eat so
much of it then. Have you ever
thought of that? Well, it's true.
7. More weddings
This girl I used to date got
married, which put me in a rotten mood. So I found out what
hotel they were staying in on
their wedding night and kept
calling up to say that there was
a bomb in one of the rooms. I
know that's probably illegal or
something, but I really got a
kick out of it.
8. Clothes
I still had a lot of money
from working for that gigantic
company, so I bought all of
these super clothes. The only
problem was that they looked
better on those mannequins
than on me. Like this Indiana

Jones hat I bought, for instance, makes me look more
like Don Knotts than Indiana
Jones. I would've taken it back
except that girls really like the
way Don Knotts looks. Really.

Amniocentesis Yields Early Sickle Cell Detection
by Robin Gugenheim

The field of prenatal
diagnosis has grown in recent
years into an exciting and
diverse science. The recent advances are a result of applying
recombinant DNA techniques
to the various problems of
clinical medicine and genetics.
Haig Kazazian Jr., M.D.,
Director of the Genetics Unit in
the Department of Pediatrics at
Hopkins, began his research
with hemoglobinopathies,
various disorders of the red
blood cell protein hemoglobin,
around 1970. Kazazian, along
with Stylianos E. Antonarakis,
M.D., Alan Scott, Ph.D., and
Corinne D. Boehm, M.S., are
presently studying DNA from
families where sickle cell
anemia, beta-thalassemia, other
hemoglobinopathies, and
hemophilia traits are present.
When prenatal diagnosis
began in 1970 not much was
known about this intriguing
field. Researchers discovered
that the beta-globin chain of
hemoglobin, that would be affected in sickle-cell anemia and
beta-thalassemia, two genetic
disorders, is produced in early
fetal life. Therefore, it would be
biologically possible to carry

out prenatal detection of these
diseases if one could get a fetal
blood sample. This analysis
depended upon the actual protein product, beta-hemoglobin,
of the beta-globin gene.
Hobbins and Mahoney at
Yale, and other groups around
the world, started developing
fetoscopy around 1975, which
is used to obtain fetal blood
samples. This procedure,
although highly successful, carries a risk of about 3 to 4 percent fatality depending upon
the skill of the obstetrician.
This test entails putting a
fiberoptic scope, with a light
source, through the abdominal
wall, through the uterus, and
into the amniotic sac. The field
of vision is very small, such
that, when looking at the extremities, only a part of the
fetus's hand can be observed at
one time. Blood is then taken
from a placental vein on the inner surface near the fetus.
Y.W. Kan in San Francisco did
the first procedures for diagnosis of sickle cell anemia and
beta-thalasSemia in 1975-6.
Sickle cell anemia and betathalassemia are two genetic
disorders where the beta-globin
chain of hemoglobin carries a
mutation that alters its chemical
structure. Sickle cell anemia can

be deadly although about half
of its victims live to 35 or 40
years of age. The red blood
cells of afflicted individuals exhibit the characteristic sickle
shape that inspired the name of
the disease. Carriers, who only
possess one affected gene, exhibit a moderate sickling of
their red blood cells. Betathalassemia, a much more
severe disease, results from a
mutation in a single nucleotide
base or a deletion of a particular region of the beta-globin
gene. These patients must be
treated with frequent blood
transfusions, but the resulting
accumulation of iron causes
premature death for most
patients.
The use of recombinant
DNA technology in 1978 was a
major breakthrough for
prenatal
diagnosis
of
hemoglobinopathies. By using
the technique of Southern Blot
Analysis one could look at the
beta-globin gene itself. This
means that the hemoglobin
molecule isn't needed and
therefore, any cell from the
body may be used for analysis,
not just red blood cells. The
DNA could be obtained by the
known
as

Balloons Used to Treat Arteries
Wider use of the balloon inflation technique instead of
bypass surgery to treat narrowed or obstructed arteries in the
leg offers the potential for
substantial cost savings without
sacrificing good patient care,
according to investigators at the
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
"While overutilization of
diagnostic radiology has been a
popular theme to explain increasing medical costs,
underutilization of interventional radiology procedures,
such as the balloon technique,
also are a factor in rising
costs," they say.
In a group of 86 patients
treated at Hopkins Hospital,
the length of stay averaged 4 to
4.5 times longer, and the total
hospital charge was 3 to 3.7
times greater for the surgical
bypass group than for the
group treated with the balloon
technique—percutaneous
transluminal angioplasty
(PTA).
The findings were presented
at the recent Radiological
Society of North America
meeting in Washington, D.C.,
by a team led by Malonnie L.
Kinnison, M.D., assistant professor of radiology.
The investigators analyzed
costs in treating diseased portions of the femoral artery,
which extends from just below
the hip to the knee, and the iliac artery, which extends from
the navel to the crease at the top
of the leg.
When these arteries become
blocked by atherosclerotic plaque, surgeons traditionally have
corrected the problem by

removing a vein from some
other area of the body and grafting it to the artery above and
below the blockage—thereby
"bypassing" the trouble spot.
In PTA, interventional
radiologists thread a catheter
with a balloon tip into the
obstructed segment of the artery
and inflate the balloon with
fluid, thus forcing open the
blocked segment.
For femoral PTA, the
average patient bill was $2,767,
which was $5,431 less than for
bypass surgery. For iliac PTA,
the average bill was $3,075,
which was $7,148 less than a
comparable bypass. The differences are exclusive of professional fees which also are higher
for surgery than for the balloon
technique.
"PTA is less expensive,"
Kinnison explains, "because
the procedure does not require
surgery or general anesthesia,
as does the bypass, and because
the length of hospital stay is
shorter for PTA patients than
for bypass patients."
For instance, for femoral
PTA patients, the length of stay
is only 3.5 days, which is 12.3
days shorter than for bypass
patients. The average length of
stay for iliac PTA patients was
3.6 days, which is 11.1 days
shorter than for bypass
patients.
Furthermore, PTA often can
be performed at the time of the
x-ray diagnostic study of the
arteries that all of these patients
must undergo, even if they are
to be treated by surgery.
"PTA for peripheral
vascular disease is an example

of the new technological
are

underutilized from both a
clinical and financial viewpoint," the authors emphasize.
Among reasons they cited for
underutilization of PTA is the
patient referral pattern. Patients traditionally are seen first
by their internist or family
physician who refers them to a
surgeon. After diagnostic
angiography, the surgeon is
then responsible for treating the
patient.
"Either because of a lack of
information, lack of a
radiologist well-trained in
angioplasty techniques, or
simply a desire to perform a
familiar and reliable procedure,
patients are not referred for
PTA."
However, "These barriers
are rapidly being eliminated by
the information now available
on the efficacy of PTA, increasing numbers of wellinterventional
trained
radiologists, and better
educated consumers."
In addition, the investigators
note, changes in the way
hospitals are reimbursed should
offer them the financial incentive to choose the least costly
method of treatment. "While
not all patients are candidates
for PTA, and those with more
severe disease are referred for
surgery," the data in the new
paper "demonstrates the potential financial benefit of performing PTA rather than
operating on suitable patients,"
the authors point out.

Enzyme Gene Code Uncovered
Robert P. Dottin;associate
professor of biology at
Hopkins, has cloned and sequenced the genetic code for
Creatine kinase (CK), an enzyme whose abnormal expression is associated with both
muscular dystrophy and cardiac hypertrophy. Cardiac
hypertrophy, which involves
enlargement of the heart, occurs in many people with
hypertension.
Dottin uncovered the
genetic code for the enzyme in
collaboration with two other
Hopkins researchers, and
reported the results in Nucleic
Acids Research, a journal

published in Great Britain.
"Although we still don't
understand the genetic factors
that control the synthesis of
this enzyme in persons with
muscular dystrophy or cardiac
hypertrophy, this is a major
advance in our research," said
Dottin. "This brings us one
step closer to understanding
what controls the expression
of the gene, which could
reveal the underlying causes
of these disorders."
Creatine kinase comes in
three different forms, and
each performs the same functions. In muscular dystrophy
and cardiac hypertrophy,

however, the relative amounts
of these forms change. Why
this happens, and why we
possess three forms of the
same enzyme, remains a
mystery.
Stress is probably a factor
in cardiac hypertrophy, since
the disease is associated with
hypertension. Finding the
connection, however, means
understanding a complex
series of biochemical events.
According to Dottin, "We
know very little about intermediate compounds that
are synthesized under stress
that may control expression of
the gene."

The Hopkins men's and

King's College Saturday in the

the majority of the men's squad
travelled to the University of
Maryland, but fell to the Terrapins, 78-34.
Royal error aids women

The men's squad won easily
and the women gained a forfeit
due to a mistake by King's.
Under MAC rules, a team must
swim six conference meets in
order to qualify for the championships. Athletic Director
Bob Scott had signed a contract
with the King's College athletic
director to swim a dual meet.
Originally scheduled for Saturday, February 2, the meet was
postponed due to snow.
The meet was rescheduled
because both the men's and the
women's teams needed to fill
their quota of six. Unfortunately, King's College does not have
a women's swimming program.
It is unclear whether the King's
director was aware of this fact,
or whether he misunderstood
the agreement. The Lady Jays
swam the meet anyway, and
were fortunately awarded the
forfeit.
